President Obama, Rhenus Sports Arena, Strasbourg, France, April 3, 2009"My job to the Muslim world is to communicate that the Americans are not your enemy. We sometimes make mistakes. We have not been perfect. But if you look at the track record, as you say, America was not born as a colonial power, and that the same respect and partnership that America had with the Muslim world as recently as 20 or 30 years ago, there's no reason why we can't restore that." President Obama, interview with Al Arabiya, January 27, 2009"All of us must now renew the common stake that we have in one another. I know that promises of partnership have gone unfulfilled in the past, and that trust has to be earned over time. While the United States has done much to promote peace and prosperity in the hemisphere, we have at times been disengaged, and at times we sought to dictate our terms. But I pledge to you that we seek an equal partnership. There is no senior partner and junior partner in our relations; there is simply engagement based on mutual respect and common interests and shared values. So I'm here to launch a new chapter of engagement that will be sustained throughout my administration." President Obama, Hyatt Regency, Port of Spain, Trinidad and Tobago, April 17, 2009"I would like to think that with my election and the early decisions that we've made, that you're starting to see some restoration of America's standing in the world. And although, as you know, I always mistrust polls, international polls seem to indicate that you're seeing people more hopeful about America's leadership." President Obama, ExCel Center, London, United Kingdom, April 2, 2009"Unfortunately, faced with an uncertain threat, our government made a series of hasty decisions. I believe that many of these decisions were motivated by a sincere desire to protect the American people. But I also believe that all too often our government made decisions based on fear rather than foresight; that all too often our government trimmed facts and evidence to fit ideological predispositions. Instead of strategically applying our power and our principles, too often we set those principles aside as luxuries that we could no longer afford. And during this season of fear, too many of us--Democrats and Republicans, politicians, journalists, and citizens--fell silent. In other words, we went off course. And this is not my assessment alone. It was an assessment that was shared by the American people who nominated candidates for President from both major parties who, despite our many differences, called for a new approach--one that rejected torture and one that recognized the imperative of closing the prison at Guantanamo Bay." President Obama, speech at the National Archives, Washington, D.C., May 21, 2009"Our two republics were founded in service of these ideals. In America, it is written into our founding documents as "life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness." In France: "Liberté"--absolutely--"egalité, fraternité." Our moral authority is derived from the fact that generations of our citizens have fought and bled to uphold these values in our nations and others. And that's why we can never sacrifice them for expedience's sake. That's why I've ordered the closing of the detention center in Guantanamo Bay. That's why I can stand here today and say without equivocation or exception that the United States of America does not and will not torture. In dealing with terrorism, we can't lose sight of our values and who we are. That's why I closed Guantanamo. That's why I made very clear that we will not engage in certain interrogation practices. I don't believe that there is a contradiction between our security and our values. And when you start sacrificing your values, when you lose yourself, then over the long term that will make you less secure." President Obama, Rhenus Sports Arena, Strasbourg, France, April 3, 2009"Every challenge that we face is more easily met if we tend to our own democratic foundation. This work is never over. That's why, in the United States, we recently ordered the prison at Guantanamo Bay closed. That's why we prohibited--without exception or equivocation--the use of torture. All of us have to change. And sometimes change is hard. Another issue that confronts all democracies as they move to the future is how we deal with the past. The United States is still working through some of our own darker periods in our history. Facing the Washington Monument that I spoke of is a memorial of Abraham Lincoln, the man who freed those who were enslaved even after Washington led our Revolution. Our country still struggles with the legacies of slavery and segregation, the past treatment of Native Americans. Human endeavor is by its nature imperfect. History is often tragic, but unresolved, it can be a heavy weight. Each country must work through its past. And reckoning with the past can help us seize a better future." President Obama to the Turkish Parliament, Ankara, Turkey, April 6, 2009"Too often, the United States has not pursued and sustained engagement with our neighbors. We have been too easily distracted by other priorities, and have failed to see that our own progress is tied directly to progress throughout the Americas. My Administration is committed to the promise of a new day. We will renew and sustain a broader partnership between the United States and the hemisphere on behalf of our common prosperity and our common security." President Obama: "Choosing a Better Future in the Americas," April 16, 2009"There is also no question that Guantanamo set back the moral authority that is America's strongest currency in the world. Instead of building a durable framework for the struggle against al Qaeda that drew upon our deeply held values and traditions, our government was defending positions that undermined the rule of law. In fact, part of the rationale for establishing Guantanamo in the first place was the misplaced notion that a prison there would be beyond the law--a proposition that the Supreme Court soundly rejected. Meanwhile, instead of serving as a tool to counter terrorism, Guantanamo became a symbol that helped al Qaeda recruit terrorists to its cause. Indeed, the existence of Guantanamo likely created more terrorists around the world than it ever detained. So the record is clear: Rather than keeping us safer, the prison at Guantanamo has weakened American national security. It is a rallying cry for our enemies." President Obama, speech at the National Archives, Washington, D.C., May 21, 2009

message: No, Sanders does not have a distinguished career.  Look at his record and this becomes very obvious:  he proposes a large number of legislative bills, almost none of which ever get out of committee and even fewer of which get enacted.  His success rate is deplorable.  He either has really bad ideas, or he is a really bad leader, or both; it doesn't really matter because either one effectively disqualifies him from being President.  His ideas sound great: "free" college, "free" health care, expanded Social Security benefits (at a time when Soc Sec is in financial straits???), "government-funded" elections, etc etc infinitum ad nauseam - same old drivel from the same old playbook that boils down to increased taxation and burdens on the citizens.Still, however, he is not a Democrat and he is truly challenging Hillary in the polls - that is very telling. message: It would cut out the insurance companies who do no actual healthcare. They are mere financial intermediaries. If you want to know how medicare would work just look at how it worked for people over 65. It works exceeding well for them.    What makes you think it would cut out insurance companies?   Medicare only covers 80% of Part B allowable health care costs.   Limited coverage is covered at 60% to 70%.    Medicare recipients must buy private supplemental health care insurance (upwards to $400/month) to cover the Medicare deductibles.    II’m over 65 – I know how it works.   It does NOT work exceedingly well.Admin cost for Medicare are lower than the private sector. Admin costs are lower because Medicare pays a flat rate and the recipients pay the difference.   The Medicare reimbursement has been reduced, and many doctors will no longer accept new Medicare patients if they do not have private supplemental insurance. Germany, France, Japan, Canada. They all have single payer system which are just a little more than 1/2 as expensive as our with the same of better outcomes. Japan and France offer single pay health insurance – it is very costly.   Their costs are lower – not because it is single payer – the costs are lower because they do not offer free health care to anyone who is not in the system as they do here in the US.    If the US reversed EMTALA (which Japan and France do not have) – and forced illegal aliens to pay for their own health insurance, we would save $90B a year.Germany has public/private, tiered insurance programs … it is not single payer.   Canada is now introducing private health insurance providers, doctors and hospitals because the people are tired of waiting in long queues and traveling to larger provinces for services not available in their province. =============================There is no evidence anywhere --   and you still didn't  answer my question – how do you propose Medicare for $300M people will be funded?

author: Tim Howe

message:
Every other day Politico runs a piece like this about Biden.  Citing "sources" who claim he "leaked" the story to Dowd, as though talking to a reporter whom he has known personally for years constitutes a "leak."  The fact that he had talked about it to other people before he relayed it to Dowd (the WSJ reported on it in June) makes the piece even less credible.  Biden is an infamous "talker", and in recent months he has, naturally, wanted to talk about Beau. 

Then there are multiple stories expressing skepticism about his path to the nomination, questioning his motivation, suggesting he would be a "spoiler" who stood in the way of progress, etc.  I'm sorry, but if there is anyone who would be running for himself/herself, out of ambition and not for the country, it is Clinton. Biden is the one who has been in public service his whole life and not made himself a fortune.  Clinton?  No.

This piece is correct that Clinton thinks she was "robbed," and that any candidate who dares enter the race and possibly beat her out for the nomination is "robbing" her.  Ditto for her diehard supporters. This is a democracy and if she can't handle the competition, maybe she isn't such a great candidate.  No doubt she would come out guns blazing, and that's fair.  But if she loses, she loses fair and sqaure and to whine she was "robbed" - especially when she has such an advantage with the establishment - would be poor sportsmanship to put it mildly.

Biden and Clinton align politically on many issues, that is true.  But that does not mean there is no place for him in the race.  Because political alignment is where their similarities, their strengths and weaknesses, stop.  They are cut from different cloth, and he would be an entirely different kind of leader than she would be.  People should not forget that many, especially among the Republicans, have a strong aversion to her.  Biden is a deal-maker, and would be better able to get things done in this bitterly divided climate.  

It's not just about winning the primary.  It's about winning the general.  If the party wants to keep the WH, maybe they should consider who is polling better against Republicans.  Biden.  Who has higher favorables among moderate voters in swing states?  Biden.

message: There is no question, gun control is part of the solution. But it's only part of the solution to violence by the untreated seriously mentally ill. There is legislation right now that could result in curtailing a significant amount of violence that results when those with a severe brain diseases are in psychosis. Oct 7 is National Helping Families in Mental Health Crisis Day. This is a day of action for urging legislators to support HR2646 to reform America's broken mental health care system. The lack of services for those with the most severe brain diseases such as schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and major depression wreaks destruction on the lives of those who are ill and their families. We have a chance to change the landscape of America's mental health care that has not occurred in more than 50 years. Five minutes of your time on Oct 7th could mean the difference between a life worth living vs. a life of homelessness, incarceration, and death for those who are the sickest. http://mentalillnesspolicy.org/.../1pagesummaryhr2646.html

One can be a great supporter of trade while absolutely not supporting an unelected tribunal being allowed to decide if your country has to pay a corporation big bucks when reasonable laws undermine their "expected profits" from raping and poisoning your environment or undermining your local economy. 

This is not about pro-trade and anti-trade - it's about whether this agreement is in the interests of the American people or of multinational corporations. And I know where I come down on that question. 

---- Steve

message:
Here is an interesting one if Trump or Sanders get elected they can TARIFF AT WILL & congress can't do jack.  Academics & constitutional lawyers may be discussing this in 2016 if one of them win... Talk about making for dramatic politics.

The Trade Act of 1974
The act delegated significant power to the president to invoke measures to protect American industries from increased imports from other nations, whether or not injury was being caused by unfair trade practices.
The act’s primary importance lies in Title II, Section 201, which gives the PRESIDENT the authority to take actions to protect U.S. businesses from injury caused by increased quantities of imports, even though the increase in imports violates no ban on unfair trade practices.
THE PRESIDENT CAN JUST DO IT

CONSTITUTIONAL BASIS FOR THE ACT
Article II of the U.S. Constitution has been interpreted to vest authority to conduct foreign policy in the president, but Article 8, Section 1 gives Congress the power to lay and collect duties and the power to regulate foreign commerce. Therefore the power to regulate trade with other nations must be delegated by Congress to the president.
Section 301 expanded presidential authority to retaliate against trade practices by other nations that unfairly burden or restrict U.S. commerce, whether through high tariffs or through nontariff trade barriers. The president may suspend trade concessions, impose new higher tariff rates on a selective basis
IMPACT OF THE ACT
Primarily because of Section 301, the Trade Act has been used more to open foreign markets to U.S. exports and investments than to protect American industries from unfair competition. Section 301 is a unilateral provision in U.S. law that can be invoked irrespective of any remedies available under the multilateral GATT or WTO.
Although the United States has generally upheld its treaty obligations under the GATT, Section 301 actions or threats of action, despite at times creating resentment from U.S. trading partners, have been highly effective tools in negotiating trade concessions.
author: Brent Holbert

message:
WHAT IS THE TPP'S "INDEPENDENT DISPUTE RESOLUTION TRIBUNAL"?
If you, acting through your representative and your government, decide to do something that will promote the common welfare, but may be detrimental to the plans and profits of a corporation, that corporation can take your nation (or your city or county or State) to "Invester-State Dispute Resolution" (ISDS) or, in the case of TPP, an "Independent Dispute Resolution Tribunal".
Corporations will rule the ISDS in fact and in function, because though you may be "represented" you and your representatives will not have the same access or resources possessed by corporations who will have at least 1/3 of the three seats on the Tribunal. 
So, kiss it good bye for national sovereignty and for the common welfare.
author: Sean Brackett

message:
WITH TPP CORPORATIONS ARE JUDGE AND JURY ADMINISTERING THEIR OWN LAW
Corporations will become the final arbiters of what is legal and illegal in every country and decisions of the international "dispute resolution tribunal" will trump any laws passed by your Representatives - Local. State. or Federal.
Nobel Prize Winning Economist Joseph Stiglitz has called the independent dispute resolution process "corrupt": 
“Even people who are arbitrators say the whole system is corrupt, that it’s a very expensive system, that therefore creates an un-even playing field with big corporations with big, deep pockets can get access to have recourse, whereas smaller firms can’t. 
"That American firms can re-locate or do their investments in the United States as a subsidiary, sue the U.S. government in ways that they could not if we didn’t have that trade agreement. In other words, what we’re doing is changing the legal structure for the United States, not only for foreign firms. … 
It’s not just a trade agreement, it’s a really major change in a legal structure.”
author: Sean Brackett

message:
NO, TPP WILL NOT “LIBERALIZE TRADE”. IT WILL FATTEN PROFITS.
TPP “was designed to redistribute more income to sectors like the pharmaceutical industry, the financial industry, and the entertainment industry, to use an international agreement to over-ride national and subnational governments that might pass laws to protect workers, consumers, or the environment. …
"...a quite explicit purpose of the deal, as noted in this article, is to increase protectionism in the form of longer and stronger patent and copyright protection. It is wrong to say that the TPP will liberalize trade. It is entirely possible that the net effect of the deal will be to increase the size of the trade barriers between the countries in the pact.”
Source: Dean Baker, Center for Policy and Economic Research

In order to ensure "adequate" profits to capital, workers' incomes had to be curtailed. The situation was set forth with unusual candor by former IMF Director Jacques de Larosière. In a 1984 policy address, he said:

"Over the last four years the rate of return on capital investment in manufacturing in the six largest industrial countries averaged only half the rate earned during the late 1960s. . . . Even allowing for cyclical factors, a clear pattern emerges of a substantial and progressive long-term decline in rates of return on capital. There may be many reasons for this. But there is no doubt that an important contributing factor is to be found in the significant increase over the past 20 years or so in the share of income being absorbed by compensation of employees . . . This points to the need for a gradual reduction in the rate increase in real wages over the medium term if we are to it restore adequate investment incentives."

message: In the late 70s a massive cattle ranch just south of Denver was purchased by the Mission Viejo Corp. of California. The company announced plans to create a city of 100,000 essentially sprawling across the southern section of the Denver metro area. That was when Coloradans were running around with bumper stickers on their cars reading: “Don’t Californicate Colorado.” At the time I was the public information director for the newly formed Colorado Office of Energy Conservation, created in response to the Arab Oil Embargo and to start the drive toward energy independence. The director of the office, University of Denver professor Buie Seawall, and I met with a Mission Viejo executive to encourage the company to adopt passive solar energy designs and a serious internal transportation plan in their community design. Naturally, we were ignored. Highlands Ranch is now a sprawling suburb of 100,000. Hey, the folks there are nice, the neighborhoods just fine – except everything is traditional late 20th Century stick construction, oversized, inefficient, with curcey roads and no coherent internal mass transit circulation system, so two and a half cars per person are still necessary. The anti-efficiency argument--people would not buy passively designed energy efficient homes. Of course, today, Highlands Ranch families are stuck with the high energy bills. The fornicators won.

Billionaire Norman Braman...As early as 2008, Mr. Braman made a bold prediction, captured in a video tribute to his friend: Mr. Rubio would be the first Hispanic president of the United States. Seeing that through in 2016, Mr. Braman said in one of the interviews, is “part of my legacy.” A detailed review of their relationship shows that Mr. Braman, 82, has left few corners of Mr. Rubio’s world untouched. message:
A constitution is an offer in contemplation of a unilateral contract.   The offer comes from the people and is accepted when staff wins elections or passes civil service exams.  "States" and "legislatures" form no part of a constitutional process.  

The unapproved Constitution the gov't uses now is a religious document not a political document.   The people are asked to take it on faith for centuries.   Staff is sworn to defend "the Constitution."  The Knights Templar were sworn to defend Christianity.   An unapproved constitution has the same legal authority as the Gospels, the Quran, or Dianetics.  The unapproved Constitution the gov't uses now is a violation of the principle of separation of church and state.

"The Constitution" isn't legal authority until after it's been approved by a majority of living voters.   Each of us has to define his risk before cooperating with strangers.

Otherwise, they might vote on and do just about anything.
author: George Gray

message:
So many issues here.  

Abortion clinics and doctors - I actually see absolutely nothing wrong with requiring the clinics to maintain standards of surgical centers and I question why women would not want them to.  Women deserve top notch facilities that are able to deal with a myriad of complications.  As for doctors having admitting privileges...why the hell not?  If they are performing the procedure and something goes wrong, you can be damn sure that they need to be the one responsible for admitting a patient.  The question is...why don't they?  If the clinics and doctors truly want to provide the best care for their female patients...they would comply with these things.  The fact that the doctors do not makes them sound like those traveling abortionists from pre-Roe v Wade.

Religious non-profits and Obamacare - Don't see a problem with this either.  HHS is more than capable of providing free birth control for women without involving these groups.  What angers me though is that free contraception is part of health plans in the first place.  If you are taking it for the sole purpose of preventing pregnancy - take some responsibility for your own actions and pay for it yourself.  The rest of us should not have to support you in this manner.  No one paid for us - we exercised personal responsibility and it did not break the bank...AND it wasn't even covered by any prescription co-pay program.

One person - one vote - The question is - why are these people included in a count for ANYTHING having to do with an election.  The same goes for the fact that the federal census is used to determine members in the electoral college...and that counts non-citizens as well.  This means that these non-citizens and illegal residents actually have a voice and impact our federal elections and THAT should not be happening.

While I was once supportive of Affirmative Action buying into the spin that was used by almost every teacher and professor I ever had, life has shown me something about reality.  Advancing someone, giving them a job, a contract, admitting them to a university merely because of the color of their skin - no because they are the best and brightest only serves to continue racial strife in this country.  

And finally, the labor union dues issue.  THere is something inherently wrong with forcing someone to pay you due in order to work and then taking that money and using it for the purpose of advancing the political agendas of hierarchy of a union.  You should NOT be forced to pay dues unless you choose to join a union and even then, you should be able to deny them the right to use that money for political purposes.  If I were a teacher, I would be screaming from the mountaintop about the NEAs decision to endorse Clinton...I would imagine that there are quite a large number of teachers that are doing the same.

message:
Bravo! Mr. Katz. This story is the political history of my life.  As a teenager, I watched these men step off their private airplanes in Spartanburg, SC -- Milliken, Kohler, and so many others.  On the day of the air traffic controller's strike -- with civilian air traffic grounded -- Senator Thurmond carried right on campaigning with a military aircraft as transportation. 

I never understood why the South was so anti-union until I was an adult and started discovering the hidden, buried secrets of the South's past -- The Uprising of '34, the textile workers killed in Honea Path, etc.  Your article is like discovering a key piece of the jigsaw puzzle -- allowing me a clearer view of the bigger picture.  It's a perfect fit.

message:
This would be a great article if it wasn't breathlessly oversold. Left out entirely is the story of the rise of Evangelicals in politics (you can find similar articles that tell that side but ignore the Milliken-Goldwater one told here--without both, you have half the tale at best). I think another part of the story that almost never gets told, perhaps partly because many of the older journalistic corporations would embarass themselves in the telling, is the role of anti-communism in the revival of the Republican Party. Public perceptions of where Reagan and Carter stood on opposition to the USSR, both substantively and in terms of competence, certainly played a role in the 1980 election and corresponding realignment.

Again, this would be a great piece if it didn't claim to be more than it is. Nevertheless, a worthwhile read.

message:
{As the Reagan conservatives were busy remaking Washington in 1981, many Americans felt they had just gotten over an unusually rough decade. Two recessions and rising oil prices had cut deeply into profits. A surge in imports, fomented by overseas investment and trade liberalization dating to the Eisenhower administration, was crushing manufacturing with a ferocity that made the 1956 Japanese “dollar blouse” crisis look quaint. Every week, another American textile mill closed.

But the downturn wasn’t temporary. After World War II, a third of U.S. workers had been employed in an industrial sector that produced sixty percent of the world’s manufactured goods. By Milliken’s death in 2010, industry’s share of the U.S. workforce would drop to one in ten. The U.S. trade deficit in goods today stands at more than $740 billion.}-

IF the GOP had remained pro TARIFF and in favor of strictly limited and controlled immigration they would not be facing certain demographic extiction to the permanent rising share of the population that is Government welfare dependent. "Free" trade combined with mass immigration for cheap labor guarantees a near permanent State of a declining wage scale combined with a rising number of people on Government assistance. Economic EQUILIBRIUM under "free"  trade means wages and standards in the USA must continuing declining until they reach their new "normal" at parity with the World's far lower median averages. 

Poverty guarantees welfare dependent "reliable" Democratic voters, the GOP establishment offering nothing to entice voters who already pay no Federal income tax. The GOP is in the bizzare situation where its chief "donors"- "free" trade multinational corporations and the financial sector- are hardcore advocates and directly profit from the policies that guarantee the demise of the Party. One would think a political Party's chief goal is to win elections.

Either the GOP establishment will change change its position on the twin key issues of TARIFFS and mass immigration for cheap labor or they will simply cease to exist as a national political Party. Their current "donor" class will most likely have to be changed to achieve that.

Read more: http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2015/10/roger-milliken-republican-party-history-213212#ixzz3nY7dWMNe

message:
Boehner's OUSTER  is political Karma....he tried to do it in 1997 to Newt Gingrich...so he gets to reap what he sews.

In scheming to be rid of House Speaker Gingrich, DeLay and his co-conspirators showed all the talent for intrigue of Peter Sellers in his Pink Panther days. Depending on who’s doing the telling, the schemers included one, two or all three of the other House leaders ranked directly below the Speaker–majority leader Dick Armey, G.O.P. conference chairman John Boehner and leadership chairman Bill Paxon–not to mention 20 or more insurgents from the rank and file. Cooked up in secrecy, the coup collapsed before it could begin. The result was a week of backstabbing that left Gingrich weaker yet more entrenched….

The plan was to have Armey, DeLay, Boehner and Paxon present Gingrich with a fait accompli: step aside or be voted out by parliamentary maneuver. What happened next is murky. By some accounts, when DeLay reported back to his fellow leaders later that Thursday night, he brought news that the rebels wanted Gingrich to be succeeded by Paxon, not Armey, who was next in line. Early Friday, Armey told his colleagues that he spent the night “praying with my wife” and decided he could not support the coup. “When Armey realized he wasn’t going to be Speaker, he backed out,” insists a knowledgeable source.

message:
Anyone who looks back on US political history knows that harsh language and wild accusations have been part of this country's electoral process since its earliest history. Look back at the claims made by John Adams and Thomas Jefferson in their contest for the presidency, and Trump sounds like a polished gentleman. 
George W Bush was called Hitler, Bill Clinton derided as a 'horndog', and critics accused LBJ of being involved in the Kennedy assassination. Read Horace Greeley's attacks on Abraham Lincoln, and view the vile editorial cartoons depicting him as a gorilla. 
Not a single primary vote has been cast, yet folks are hyperventilating about The Donald's standing in the polls. This time next year, we're likely to be deluged with negative ads and ad hominem attacks from all concerned, so enjoy the show before we're standing at a polling place wishing we had the option to choose, "None of the above".

message: How the nations so called "justice system" fails everyone: Despite the fact that the nation’s courtrooms remain active crime scenes, with backdated, forged and fabricated documents still sloshing around them, state and federal regulators have not filed new charges of misconduct against Bank of America, Deutsche Bank, U.S. Bank, Green Tree, or any other mortgage industry participant, since the round of national settlements over foreclosure fraud ineffectively closed the issue.The BANKSTERS continue to commit fraud upon hardworking people and fraud upon the courts. The biggest Ponzi scheme the world has ever seen , where the Banksters created credit out of thin air, not for their borrowers, but for the banksters themselves via the Federal Reserve’s magic check book, with no bank account behind it. The Bankster then loaned that imaginary money to people on the security of overvalued real property with the deliberate aim of reducing the artificially raised property prices and putting people out of work.People without income cannot pay their bills, so they were guaranteed they could steal all that real property from their rightful owners. Of course you would say to yourself, that makes no sense because the Banksters would lose money when foreclosing on the security , but you’d be wrong because the banksters insured the debt with an insurance company, but just forgot to tell the borrowers that. SO they knew they could not lose. Its what you might call having your cake and eating it too. You see, just secretly insuring the debt was the way they ensured that they lost no money. First they sold investors in Wall Street on the idea of using pensions and other fund moneys to invest in the profitable housing market. Then they sold homeowners on the idea of borrowing money against their rising property values, secure in knowing that they had artificially raised those prices and knew they could reverse that trend rapidly, when the time was right. Then they found another group of investors and sold them on insuring against the unlikely risk of those secure mortgages defaulting. But, as you know, they had already insured the downside risk. So they devised a new name that no one understood called the credit default swap. These were not insurance policies regulated by the states, but were unregulated securities sold on wall street to investors. So, once they got the business of insurance outside of the regulatory realm, it was no holds barred and they sold the same investment to up to 20 different groups in respect of every mortgage pool they pretended to create in the securitized mortgage scam.But people need to lose the mindset of someone who has been brainwashed by the garbage put out by government at state and federal level and echoed in the corporate owned media.SO therefore, The banksters along side Freddie and Fannie, were and still are continuing to submit fraudulent documents to the courts in order to steal homes from homeowners. They and their substitute trustee lawyers (ie Samuel I White PC, just one of many ) are submitting FRAUDULENT papers to the courts in order to FRAUDULENTLY foreclose on homeowners across the nation. Mortgage notes with Forged Owners signatures and ta-da endorsements are being submitted to the courts in order to steal homes. Bank of america(or as they like to refer to themselves…fka countrywide) made a deal with the attorney generals to modify loans that they really had no right to modify as they were illegally acquired to begin with. They committed notary fraud, forgery, added fake endorsements and as their crimes began to come to light…………they made a deal and instead of modifications (which they LED the homeowners to believe what was happening)….they handed the fraudulent documents over to Green Tree, now known as Ditech: corporate criminals are notorious for changing their names after lights shine on their crimes…, among others, to foreclose. Meanwhile, homeowners are the ones who are paying the price by having their homes taken because of felonies that are being committed . Fraud upon the courts, racketeering, forgery, wire fraud, notary fraud…pathetic, nauseating, and just all around COMPLETELY disgusting. Meanwhile,a large majority of the so called judges are just as corrupt and right in bed with the pathetic, slimeball, evil to the core, corporate criminals and don't care about what is right and what is wrong and what is criminal. message: The banks are paid by the investors for servicing the loan. The incentive to delay modifications and to pursue foreclosure is purely profit. They get paid more for a foreclosure, and every month they delay a modification is another month they earn money for servicing the loan. Since servicing a loan is largely automatic, it costs next to nothing to service a loan, and every loan modified means lower income. For the banks to claim that they have no reason to delay is a lie.To process modifications efficiently, it means more hiring and more expense. So the banks face a double whammy to modify the loan- upfront and post mod- and they know it.

message:
Since some of the posters here seem to be a bit confused about why Dodd-Frank has proven to be so inadequate, I'd like to give you a little recent history lesson. Let me preface this by saying that I'm NOT a Democrat nor a Liberal. There are plenty of scummy things I can point to Democrats doing if you like. What I'm posting isn't party politics, it's just facts. I encourage you to look it up.

Immediately after Dodd-Frank's passage Republicans began working full steam to try and roll back the legislation. 
http://www.politico.com/story/2014/12/wall-street-spending-bill-congress-113525
They even got through house bill HR 992 (which was thankfully killed in the senate) to completely remove regulation on derivative trading, the financial instrument that was almost entirely responsible for our financial collapse. HR 992 was directly copied from proposed legislation by citi bank.
http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2013/05/citigroup-hr-992-wall-street-swaps-regulatory-improvement-act
While some absolutely scummy Democrats voted for the legislation, the bill enjoyed the full support of the entire Republican house.

Also worth reading.
http://www.forbes.com/sites/stevedenning/2014/12/12/with-dodd-frank-rollback-the-big-bad-banks-are-back/
http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-financial-regulation-shelby-dodd-frank-20150521-story.html

Republicans have also worked at length to curtail the power of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ranging from fillibustering the agency head, defund attempts, and full on attempts to repeal the agency.
http://thehill.com/policy/finance/206371-gop-prepares-slew-of-bills-targeting-consumer-financial-protection-bureau
http://www.stlamerican.com/business/business_opinion/article_6698af08-4c48-11e5-b92a-f39e3654ad1c.html

message: Liberals often claim that the rich paid a 91% income tax rate during the Eisenhower years, and while it is true that the top marginal rate was 91% from 1954 to 1963 that is not what matters. The important part is how much the rich actually paid.Here were the effective individual income tax rates of the 3 very high income AGI groups.$200,000-$500,000 group: Tax as Share of Amended AGI (%)1953 = 45.91954 = 39.31955 = 36.81956 = 37.41957 = 38.61958 = 36.91959 = 33.81960 = 33.11961 = 31.5$500,000-$1,000,000 group: Tax as Share of Amended AGI (%)1953 = 46.31954 = 38.71955 = 35.61956 = 36.71957 = 36.61958 = 36.01959 = 32.11960 = 30.81961 = 29.1Over $1,000,000 group: Tax as Share of Amended AGI (%)1953 = 49.31954 = 38.81955 = 35.81956 = 36.11957 = 40.01958 = 33.11959 = 30.61960 = 31.31961 = 27.2SOURCE: William Williams, The Changing Progressivity of the Federal Income Tax, National Tax Journal (1964)Quote:In 1954, for example, the 0.3 percent of the taxpayers with more than $40,000 AGI reported almost $13 billion in AGI (including 100 percent of capital gains but excluding exempt interest); yet their effective tax rates ranged from as little as 27 percent to 39 percent—far from the infamous rates conjured up by the Code tables.SOURCE: Eisenhower-Era Marxist-Confiscatory Taxation: Requiem for the Rhetoric of Rate Reduction for the Richhttp://ir.uiowa.edu/cgi/viewco...So the rich really didn't pay anything close to 91% during the Eisenhower years, and their effective tax rate was steadily reduced.http://boards.straightdope.com...

author: David

message: Social Security increase was $3.00 last year, and $0 for the two previous years!  The government says it is indexed to inflation, but they use a "different inflation rate" that doesn't take gasoline, fuel oil, and food into the equation. (I guess because seniors don't buy gasoline, fuel oil, or food).  ;-}The big push for raising the minimum wage is coming from the unions, because their contracts are indexed to the minimum wage.  When the Minimum Wage goes up, all the union members will automatically get the same increase. When the M W goes up 20% they all get a 20% raise.  It will be the Jimmy Carter years all over again, with double digit inflation, double digit interest rates, and double digit unemployment.  That increase that looks so benign when they show it to us, will ripple through the economy, and everyone will be affected, especially the Seniors on a fixed income.  Then the Seniors will have to take those Minimum Wage jobs to survive.  Is that the kind of retirement all of you want?...moving to a condo in Florida, or getting up every morning to go to work at McDonald's, until you are 90?

author: Terry Mitchell

message: My brother used to own a painting business in California and his employees were in the union.  When the economy failed in 2007 and the contracts were not coming in the men threatened a strike for more wages and for him to pay for all of their medical.  In order for him to meet these demands he would have to raise his prices, but with the economy failing, he had no choice but to shut his business down and file bankruptcy.  My brother started his business in 1976 with just himself and his brother-in-law and when he shut it down in 2009 he had to lay off 35 employees.  If it wasn't for the union, I honestly feel that my brother could have saved his business that he worked so hard to keep going.  My father used to say this about unions "When unions want the workers to go on strike, the workers will always take the biggest loss, by this I mean, think about it, the union officials will still get paid their full wages, but the workers will not receive any paychecks while on strike nor can they collect unemployment benefits, they will get $25.00 a week to man the picket lines so, in the long run the workers will never get back all the wages they lose while they strike.".
author: Chacooe

message: think about this.....before unions, kids 6 and over worked 12-16 hours a day, in chained up wooden factories, with bad lighting and unsafe working conditions. adults worked long hours as well, both could work 6-7 days a week.They worked in unsafe working conditions for bad pay. Unions helped get us a 40 hour work week, weekends, kids out of the workforce....sick leave, pensions, and health care. Unions caused us to raise the standard of living for the majority of Americans. That made us the envy of the rest of the world. As unions have declined in the US for the last 30 yrs, our standard of living has gone down. Now we are in at least 16th place for social mobility and standard of living.On top of that, safety has gone downhill in the work place. I am truly sorry that your brother lost his business, but because of declining numbers of unions and lack safety regulations, my son-in-law died. While my grandchildren each got 1 million dollars in the end.....they would have far rather had their beloved father. And he was a loving, active father who waited to have kids and who enjoyed watching his offspring grow up. I mourn for my family's loss, but I also mourn for the enjoyment that he lost.

And prevent it from slipping further. At one time we were taught that a kid born in a log cabin could grow up and be president, alluding to the social mobility that existed in America but we are 16 th now in that as well.That means that at least 15 other nations have a higher standard of living than the US and have more social mobility.....we can't continue to benefit from being a world leader when we can't even take care of Americans and solve our own problems.

author: elbarto

message: Yeah, they should have killed off Han--giving the movies extra emotional weight. He should have died attacking the Deathstar. Luke's twin should have been another girl, not Leia. And Luke should have gotten the girl, that being Leia. Jedi was a horribly flawed movie from minute one, through to the ending. The Jabba scenes didn't work, and the rescue of Han came far too easy. The Empire should have been waiting for the rebel rescuers of Han as a trap, and it should have resulted in Lando having recruited other pirates at Mos Eisley who are allies of Han and himself to attack and help free him and the others. BTW, there is a sandstorm scene that was cut from the movie, one that was really nice. It unfolds as Han, Leia and Luke are getting ready to leave the planet after Han's rescue. I am shocked that they didn't use it, for it is that handsome??? Oh, and the Teddy Bears, that was yet another major flaw. The Ewoks should have been shown as the children of the Wookies, and it is the Wookies that should have fought the Empire in the final battle, both on the ground and in space, not the Teddy Bears. Finally, Luke's training as a Jedi, ended far too abruptly. He should have returned to Yoda for significantly more training...and only should have been told that he had passed his final test, by bring his father back to the light side of the force. That is when Yoda should have told him, you are now worthy of being a Jedi, not prior.

author: GoinMobil

message: You got that part about the legal situation backwards. Yes, there's a legal assistance treaty relationship between Switzerland and the US. But that doesn't mean US laws apply in Switzerland, of course!You write: "These treaties require foreign governments to hand over to a requesting government any information legally available to their local authorities." What's important to note is that said information has to be legally available *according to local law.* And since Swiss privacy laws are very strict (while US privacy laws are not), this is a big deal.Not only is Threema, the end-to-end encrypted instant messenger also based in Switzerland, Phil Zimmermann of PGP fame moved there, as well. It wasn't because of the cows, it was because of the laws.
author: pointcheck

message: "That means that Switzerland would have to give the US access to any data that it could itself access. "
author: yael_grauer

message: No. Not "[…] that it could [sic] itself access," but "[…] that it can itself *legally* access"!And Switzerland can't legally access the same data the US could. So, again, the location makes a difference."That means that Switzerland would have to give the US access to any data that it could itself access. So if you’re planning to use ProtonMail to sell steroids, leak government secrets, or engage in FIFA-style wire fraud/money laundering/racketeering schemes, Swiss law probably won’t help you."How does the first statement support the second in any way, shape, or form?Again, ProtonMail and Threema etc. are located in Switzerland for a good reason.
author: pointcheck

message: Correct-- MLATs would require Switzerland to give the US data that Switzerland can access. Switzerland can, in fact, legally access data--see FIFA for an example. I am not a lawyer, but it's my understanding that U.S. law is sometimes more protective.
author: yael_grauer

message: Um, how's the FIFA case an example for this? (And what about the claims about selling steroids, etc.? I still don't see where those are coming from.)If the U.S. privacy laws were more protective, why would Zimmermann move from the U.S. to Switzerland? Why would Proton and Threema be located there?Anyway, I think what you're ultimately trying to say is that there are laws in other countries, too, and that there's such a thing as a MLAT, and that, therefore, it's not just "anything goes" if a company isn't located in the U.S. Fair enough.
author: pointcheck

message: I used FIFA as an example because FIFA IT data was seized by Swiss police, so people who think that Switzerland's privacy law would protect from seizure of servers (etc.) are mistaken. And then I used examples of crimes that the Swiss government would investigate and therefore the U.S. could also investigate. But yes, it's complicated. Thanks for your interest.

That's it?  An average of $128M per year of its designed life?The Golden Gate bridge is 82 years old and was designed back in the late 1920s. author: Antares14

message: Part of the problem is that today's engineers are taught to "Not Waste Materials." That, and margins for error continually are reduced with computational tools and CAD design, and consequently things simply are not as robustly built as in the past, and they wear out faster.Example: Relatively recently the bearings in the clock mechanism for London's Big Ben had to be replaced. They - Finally! - had worn out after *150 Years* (!). The engineer on the project pointed out that the Victorians had a tendency to overbuild things, to try and make them last. He then added that if the clock had been built today, the bearings might have lasted only 30 years or so.I deal with engineers constantly, and it's a continual fight to make them understand that I want things built to last, overbuilt rather than under, and to make them 'unlearn' their materials conservation engineering philosophy. After reading about the Big Ben rebuild, I've taken to describing what I want with the shorthand 'Victorian Engineering."Maybe it's time past due to reassert that "Victorian Engineering" philosophy on all public engineering projects, or anything where long-term and problem-free durability is desired or expected.Hope this helps.Just a thought.VicB3
author: VicB3

message: Maybe that materials conservation ethos is further exacerbated by our throw-away consumerist society, built-in obsolescence, and the ephemeral fashion-driven purchasing habits of consumers who then go on to replace perfectly good products just to keep "on trend".The idea of built-to-last must be antithetical for contempory engineers. Isambard Kingdom Brunel would eat his hat and choke on his cigar were he alive today!

author: infinite_realities

message: There were zero deaths from radiation at Fukushima.A nuclear war cannot make us extinct.Extinction Level Event [ELE] means one hundred million megatons.  When we [the US] and the Soviet Union had the most bombs, thirty thousand each, we had one part in ten thousand of an ELE.  We are now down to fifteen hundred each.  There has never been a possibility of making ourselves extinct by means of nuclear war.We need nuclear bombs to protect our planet from giant impacts like the one that killed the dinosaurs.  I did the calculation many years ago for Haley's Comet.   The backpack nuke is more than sufficient, and you don't even need the high 2 kiloton setting.   It is freshman undergraduate physics.
author: asteroid_miner

message: I dunno re: nukes killing off humans.  During the dark days of the late 70s and early 80s, if a full exchange happened, we're talking 30,000-50,000 nuclear weapons available. Not sure how many of those would actually make it to delivery, but everyone, and nearly every nation would be on the target list, lots of airbursts flattening and igniting cities, and ground bursts against transportation, with even the smallest switching yards or freeway interchanges getting a 'party favor'.The amount of smoke and blast particulates in the air would be more or less incalculable.  I'd fully expect multiple growing seasons to get shortened or eliminated.    This could also crash the diatom population at sea, stressing the Marine ecosystem for awhile.  Probably not permanent, but suddenly you're dealing with 5-10% of the world's previous agricultural output, and maybe 50-60% of the population.    If that isn't a recipe for chaos, I don't know what is.    Between human vs human and human vs environment, say maybe 5-10% of the world's population surviving at the end of the first decade.It isn't just about "blast" and megatons  it is all about what you do to the agricultural base / carrying capacity to the planet. Then what human nature will do in the face of desperate shortage and certain death.Like it or not, we're still dependent on 6 inches of topsoil, sunlight, and rain.
author: FredMurre

message: When you refer to an ELE you are refering to a single impact that would be equal to a specific number, and no, we don't (or didn't) have enough nuclear weapons to match that number. But the concern regarding the extinction of the human race isn't a matter of all the nuclear weapons killing everyone directly, it's the impact on the environment that could eventually cause the extinction of the human race.And, it's good to know that experts such as yourself have already solved the killer astroid/comet impact problem and have time to post on sites like this and share your knowledge so the rest of us can sleep soundly at night.
